properties.name: Battle of Artaxata
properties.description: The Romans were led by the consul Lucius Licinius Lucullus, the leader of the Armenians was Tigranes II. When attempting to take Artaxata in 68 BC, the Romans were defeated and pushed back into Mesopotamia

properties.name: Battle of Tigranocerta
properties.description: In 69 BC, the Roman commander Lucullus marched through Cappadocia, crossed the Euphrates and invaded Armenia. The Romans successfully crossed the Tigris and approached Tigranakert. Lucullus himself did not manage to take the city by storm. The gates of the capital of Great Armenia were treacherously opened by Greek mercenaries in Tigranakert. As a result, the huge and rich city became the prey of the Romans and was plundered.

properties.name: Siege of Nissibis
properties.description: After their defeat at Artaxata, the Romans were forced to retreat into Mesopotamia and fortify themselves in the city of Nisibis, which was soon besieged by Tigranes the Great

properties.name: Battle for 70 valleys agains Parthia
properties.description: In the first stage of the intervention, Tigranes recaptured 70 valleys from the Parthians, which had been ceded to them as a ransom for their liberation. The region of Akhbak in Atropatene was also taken.

properties.name: Siege of summer residence of Parthian's kings
properties.description: Tigranes captured the summer residence of the Parthian kings, the city of Ecbatana, which became from 144 BC to the time of Tigranes II the main capital of Parthia.
